citations.narrative:
The Record of Animals on hand (acquisition and disposition records) seen at time of inspection was not current or
complete. Since the last inspection, additional animals have been acquired, and others have been sold and/or disposed of
without documentation as follows:
• Acquisitions: a cow, a squirrel, goats, and pigeons.
• Dispositions: a dog, goats, and sheep.
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the
animals. The facility shall ensure that they make, keep, and maintain records that fully and correctly disclose all the
required information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which
are transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal
while in his or her possession.
Correct by 04/15/2025.

The facility does not have complete medical records (except for vaccination certificates for rabies and
distemper/parvovirus and parasite prevention medication logs) for the dogs and dog hybrid available for this inspection.
The complete records are currently kept at the attending veterinarian's office. Keeping up to date medical records is
required to verify routine preventative care, annual exam findings and appropriate treatment of any medical
conditions/injuries for the dogs and dog hybrid. The facility must keep copies of medical records for dogs and dog hybrids
that include the following required information: identifying information about each dog and dog hybrid, all preventative and
routine husbandry procedures performed, information about problems identified, treatments/vaccinations administered,
and results of all tests and examinations performed as well as make the records available for APHIS inspection.
Correct by 04/15/2025.

The primary outdoor enclosure housing a wolf did not have a perimeter fence of adequate height for dangerous species.
Instead of the required 8 feet (or 96 inches), it ranged from 92 to 94 inches tall. The lack of an adequate perimeter fence
presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an adequate secondary containment system to
hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier to keep animals and unauthorized persons
out. The facility must ensure that the wolf being housed outdoors is enclosed by a perimeter fence, 8-feet tall. The
perimeter fence must be effective, continuous, and at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosures.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The Record of Animals on hand (acquisition and disposition records) seen at time of inspection was not current or 
complete. Since the last inspection, additional animals have been acquired, and others have been sold and/or disposed of 
without documentation as follows: 
• Acquisitions: a cow, a squirrel, goats, and pigeons. 
• Dispositions: a dog, goats, and sheep.  
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition records are necessary to allow for medical and legal tracking of the 
animals. The facility shall ensure that they make, keep, and maintain records that fully and correctly disclose all the 
required information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which 
are transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal 
while in his or her possession. 
Correct by 04/15/2025. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility does not have complete medical records (except for vaccination certificates for rabies and 
distemper/parvovirus and parasite prevention medication logs) for the dogs and dog hybrid available for this inspection. 
The complete records are currently kept at the attending veterinarian's office. Keeping up to date medical records is 
required to verify routine preventative care, annual exam findings and appropriate treatment of any medical 
conditions/injuries for the dogs and dog hybrid. The facility must keep copies of medical records for dogs and dog hybrids 
that include the following required information: identifying information about each dog and dog hybrid, all preventative and 
routine husbandry procedures performed, information about problems identified, treatments/vaccinations administered, 
and results of all tests and examinations performed as well as make the records available for APHIS inspection. 
Correct by 04/15/2025. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary outdoor enclosure housing a wolf did not have a perimeter fence of adequate height for dangerous species. 
Instead of the required 8 feet (or 96 inches), it ranged from 92 to 94 inches tall. The lack of an adequate perimeter fence

presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an adequate secondary containment system to 
hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier to keep animals and unauthorized persons 
out. The facility must ensure that the wolf being housed outdoors is enclosed by a perimeter fence, 8-feet tall. The 
perimeter fence must be effective, continuous, and at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosures. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
